title: Jetex Invests In Aviation Sustainability Firm Azzera
description:
JETEX has invested in aviation sustainability technology provider Azzera, marking a strategic step aimed at accelerating lower-emission operations across the private aviation sector.
The investment positions Azzera to expand the capabilities of its digital carbon-management platform, scale its international presence, and roll out new offsetting and sustainability tools for customers.
Alongside the equity investment, JETEX has entered into a sustainability partnership with Azzera that will see the private aviation specialist begin procuring and managing sustainable aviation fuel from early 2026.
Embedding sustainability Beyond fuel management, JETEX will integrate Azzera’s FlyBeyond API into its charter sales ecosystem.
The investment completes Azzera’s $800,000 capital raise, funding further development of its digital sustainability ecosystem.
text:
JETEX has invested in aviation sustainability technology provider Azzera, marking a strategic step aimed at accelerating lower-emission operations across the private aviation sector.

The investment positions Azzera to expand the capabilities of its digital carbon-management platform, scale its international presence, and roll out new offsetting and sustainability tools for customers.

The partnership was formalised during Dubai Airshow 2025, signalling growing momentum behind technology-led approaches to aviation decarbonisation.

Alongside the equity investment, JETEX has entered into a sustainability partnership with Azzera that will see the private aviation specialist begin procuring and managing sustainable aviation fuel from early 2026.

This collaboration enables JETEX to integrate SAF into its international fleet for the first time, representing a significant shift in its operational strategy as environmental performance becomes a core priority.

Digital tools to unlock SAF adoption

A key element of the agreement sees JETEX acting as a lead partner for Azzera’s new SAF Productivity Operations and Delivery platform. Known as SAF POD, the tool is designed to address administrative and operational barriers that often slow the adoption of SAF across aviation supply chains.

For aircraft operators, SAF POD will be accessible through Azzera’s CELESTE platform, automating the conversion of digital certificates into verified emissions reductions and detailed fuel tracking.

The system also supports the issuance of Scope 1 and Scope 3 certificates, simplifying compliance and reporting requirements for operators managing increasingly complex sustainability obligations.

Azzera says the platform is intended to make SAF sourcing, tracking, and delivery more transparent and scalable, particularly for operators seeking to integrate lower-carbon fuels without adding operational burden.

Embedding sustainability

Beyond fuel management, JETEX will integrate Azzera’s FlyBeyond API into its charter sales ecosystem.

The integration allows real-time carbon offsetting and SAF quotations to be embedded directly into flight quotes, giving operators and customers the ability to make sustainability-led decisions at the point of sale.

According to Azzera chief executive Puja Mahajan, “The investment from and collaboration with JETEX demonstrates our shared vision of a future where sustainability is seamlessly embedded in every flight.”

She added that the partnership helps bridge “the gap between climate ambition and operational reality with practical tools that make sustainability accessible, transparent, and measurable.”

Supporting industry decarbonisation goals

JETEX chief executive Adel Mardini commented that the company views its role in supporting aviation’s climate ambitions as a responsibility, noting that partnering with Azzera aligns innovation with measurable environmental progress.

The collaboration reflects wider industry efforts to combine digital platforms, alternative fuels, and verified carbon markets to drive tangible emissions reductions.

The investment completes Azzera’s $800,000 capital raise, funding further development of its digital sustainability ecosystem.

This includes enhanced emissions tracking, automated compliance processes, and expanded access to high-quality carbon markets through the CELESTE platform, as aviation stakeholders face increasing pressure to demonstrate credible decarbonisation pathways.

title: Egypt & Qatar Sign USD 500 Million Sustainable Aviation Fuel Hub Deal - CairoScene
description:
Egypt has secured a USD 500 million agreement with Qatari partners to develop a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production hub in the Sokhna area of the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZONE), with Shell acting as a strategic partner and long-term offtaker.
The project will be located within the Sokhna industrial and logistics zone, taking advantage of port infrastructure and proximity to major international shipping lanes.
Under the agreement, Shell will take the entire output under a long-term supply contract, with first exports expected within 18 months of project implementation.
The SAF facility will be developed in three phases, with total production capacity expected to reach 600,000 tonnes annually at full scale.
Shell’s involvement includes technical expertise, fuel certification support, and market access, drawing on its global experience in alternative fuels and energy transition projects.
text: Egypt has secured a USD 500 million agreement with Qatari partners to develop a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production hub in the Sokhna area of the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZONE), with Shell acting as a strategic partner and long-term offtaker. The project will be located within the Sokhna industrial and logistics zone, taking advantage of port infrastructure and proximity to major international shipping lanes. Under the agreement, Shell will take the entire output under a long-term supply contract, with first exports expected within 18 months of project implementation. The SAF facility will be developed in three phases, with total production capacity expected to reach 600,000 tonnes annually at full scale. Over a ten-year period, the hub is projected to generate exports valued at approximately USD 15 billion, supplying international aviation markets across Europe, Africa, and the Middle East, where demand for low-carbon jet fuel continues to rise. Shell’s involvement includes technical expertise, fuel certification support, and market access, drawing on its global experience in alternative fuels and energy transition projects. The company’s offtake commitment provides commercial certainty for the project, supporting its phased expansion and financing structure. The development aligns with Egypt’s wider strategy to position the Suez Canal Economic Zone as a regional centre for clean fuels and green manufacturing, alongside hydrogen, methanol, and renewable energy projects already under development in Sokhna.

title: Manufacturing of sustainable aviation fuel to need prior green clearance: Environment ministry
description:
“The EIA Notification, 2006 mandates prior Environmental Clearance (EC) for the projects/activities covered in the schedule of the Notification.
The Ministry has been receiving project proposals for manufacturing of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) from biogenic feedstock, for the grant of prior EC,” said the ministry’s office memorandum dated December 11 has said.
Accordingly, the activity shall be considered under item 4(a) [Petroleum Refining Industry] of the EIA Notification, 2006, for grant of EC,” the ministry has said.
According to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) could contribute around 65% of the reduction in emissions needed by aviation to reach net zero CO2 emissions by 2050.
SAF is a liquid fuel currently used in commercial aviation which reduces CO2 emissions by up to 80%.
text:
“The EIA Notification, 2006 mandates prior Environmental Clearance (EC) for the projects/activities covered in the schedule of the Notification. The Ministry has been receiving project proposals for manufacturing of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) from biogenic feedstock, for the grant of prior EC,” said the ministry’s office memorandum dated December 11 has said.

“As the production of SAF from biogenic feedstock involves processes similar to those listed under item 4(a) [Petroleum Refining Industry] of the EIA Notification, 2006, the sectoral EAC has been granting Term of Reference to such projects under item 4(a) of the schedule of the EIA Notification 2006 on a case to case basis. In this context, in order to bring clarity, the Ministry hereby clarifies that the production of SAF involves processes such as isomerization and cracking, which are analogous to those employed in the petroleum refining industry. Accordingly, the activity shall be considered under item 4(a) [Petroleum Refining Industry] of the EIA Notification, 2006, for grant of EC,” the ministry has said.

According to the International Air Transport Association (IATA), Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) could contribute around 65% of the reduction in emissions needed by aviation to reach net zero CO2 emissions by 2050. This will require a massive increase in production in order to meet demand.

SAF is a liquid fuel currently used in commercial aviation which reduces CO2 emissions by up to 80%. It can be produced from a number of sources (feedstock) including waste oil and fats, municipal waste, and non-food crops. It can also be produced synthetically via a process that captures carbon directly from the air. It is “sustainable” because the raw feedstock does not compete with food crops or water supplies, and is not responsible for forest degradation. Whereas fossil fuels add to the overall level of CO2 by emitting carbon that had been previously locked away, SAF recycles the CO2 which has been absorbed by the biomass used in the feedstock during the course of its life.

title: Carolina Renewable Products breaks ground on $280 million renewable diesel facility
description:
Carolina Renewable Products has officially broken ground on its first renewable diesel facility in Orangeburg County, marking the launch of a $280 million clean-energy investment that will create 155 jobs over the next five years.
Located at 546 Prosperity Drive, Orangeburg, South Carolina, the 20-acre site will convert pine wood residuals from local sawmills into renewable diesel—a clean, drop-in fuel that requires no engine modifications.
The plant will also produce high-value by-products, including biochar and wood vinegar.
“Our goal is simple: bring jobs, innovation, and clean fuel production to South Carolina,” said Robert Bryan, CEO of CRP.
State and county leaders praised the project for strengthening South Carolina’s forestry sector, which has faced mill closures and shrinking markets.
text:
Carolina Renewable Products has officially broken ground on its first renewable diesel facility in Orangeburg County, marking the launch of a $280 million clean-energy investment that will create 155 jobs over the next five years.

Located at 546 Prosperity Drive, Orangeburg, South Carolina, the 20-acre site will convert pine wood residuals from local sawmills into renewable diesel—a clean, drop-in fuel that requires no engine modifications. The plant will also produce high-value by-products, including biochar and wood vinegar.

“Our goal is simple: bring jobs, innovation, and clean fuel production to South Carolina,” said Robert Bryan, CEO of CRP. “This project has been years in the making, and Orangeburg is exactly where we want to build.”

Construction begins in spring 2026, with initial modules operating by late 2026 and full operations expected by 2027. State and county leaders praised the project for strengthening South Carolina’s forestry sector, which has faced mill closures and shrinking markets.

The project is supported by county tax incentives and a $755,000 Closing Fund grant from the Coordinating Council for Economic Development and a $200,000 grant from South Carolina's Secretary of Agriculture.

title: India likely to shift to ethanol-blended aviation fuel by mid-2027: Report - ChiniMandi
description:
India has already carried out trial flights using cleaner aviation fuel.
In March 2023, Air Vistara, which has since merged with Air India, operated a long-haul Boeing 787 flight from the United States to India using fuel blended.
According to the news report, a long-pending policy on sustainable aviation fuel is likely to be released for public consultations next month, the official said, requesting anonymity.
The Centre is supporting biofuel projects through the Pradhan Mantri JI-VAN Yojana, which provides financial assistance for setting up plants, including those producing aviation fuel.
Various companies/PSUs namely Indian Oil Corporation Limited, Bharat Petroleum Limited, Hindustan Petroleum Limited, Mangalore Refinery and Petrochemicals Limited, CSIR Indian Institute of Petroleum, Chennai Petroleum Corporation Limited, Indian Institute of Petroleum etc.
text:
India is likely to shift to ethanol-blended aviation fuel by mid-2027, gradually ramping it up in phases, with the addition of more than two dozen distilleries supported by federal biofuel incentives, an official familiar with the details said on Sunday, reported Hindustan Times.

The country, which has the world’s third-largest aviation market, is aiming to introduce 1% ethanol blending in jet fuel by 2027, raise it to 2% in 2028 and further to 5% by 2030. Union Minister of State for Civil Aviation Murlidhar Mohol had shared these targets in Parliament earlier this month.

India has already carried out trial flights using cleaner aviation fuel. In March 2023, Air Vistara, which has since merged with Air India, operated a long-haul Boeing 787 flight from the United States to India using fuel blended. In the same year, Air Asia flew the country’s first commercial domestic flight between Pune and Delhi with a fuel blend.

According to the news report, a long-pending policy on sustainable aviation fuel is likely to be released for public consultations next month, the official said, requesting anonymity.

International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has adopted Carbon Offsetting & Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) as a global market-based measure to reduce emissions from international aviation which require offsetting of emissions above a baseline value. Airlines can either use SAF or offset their emissions by purchasing carbon credits from ICAO approved Emissions Unit Programmes. SAF offers a direct pathway to emission reduction by lowering the lifecycle carbon footprint of aviation fuel. When airlines adopt CORSIA Eligible SAF (CORSIA Eligible Fuel) certified against ICAO’s sustainability standards and verified through Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (MRV), they can claim these reductions as substitutes for carbon credits, thereby decreasing their offsetting obligations under the scheme.

The Centre is supporting biofuel projects through the Pradhan Mantri JI-VAN Yojana, which provides financial assistance for setting up plants, including those producing aviation fuel.

Under the scheme, the government offers interest support for five years, including a one-year repayment break, on loans taken to set up new ethanol distilleries. The support covers interest up to 6% per year or half of the bank’s lending rate, whichever is lower.

Various companies/PSUs namely Indian Oil Corporation Limited, Bharat Petroleum Limited, Hindustan Petroleum Limited, Mangalore Refinery and Petrochemicals Limited, CSIR Indian Institute of Petroleum, Chennai Petroleum Corporation Limited, Indian Institute of Petroleum etc. are currently working on SAF production/research.

title: Egypt signs $200m SAF investment with Qatar's Al Mana Holding - Utilities Middle East
description:
Egypt has signed a contract with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding for a first-phase investment of $200 million to establish a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production facility at Ain Sokhna in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, the cabinet said.
The first phase is expected to have an annual production capacity of 200,000 tonnes, according to the cabinet statement.
The agreement marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, representing a milestone in bilateral economic cooperation between Cairo and Doha.
Egypt has been seeking to attract foreign investment, particularly from Gulf states, as it works to address high external debt levels and a widening budget deficit.
The agreement follows a series of major Qatari investments in Egypt.
text:
Egypt has signed a contract with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding for a first-phase investment of $200 million to establish a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production facility at Ain Sokhna in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, the cabinet said.

According to a news report by Zawya, the project, which will be developed across three phases, will span 100,000 square metres in the Integrated Sokhna Zone on Egypt’s Red Sea coast. The first phase is expected to have an annual production capacity of 200,000 tonnes, according to the cabinet statement.

The agreement marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, representing a milestone in bilateral economic cooperation between Cairo and Doha.

Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly said the project reflects growing momentum in Egypt–Qatar relations, driven by a shared political will to expand cooperation through joint investments and increased trade.

Egypt has been seeking to attract foreign investment, particularly from Gulf states, as it works to address high external debt levels and a widening budget deficit.

The agreement follows a series of major Qatari investments in Egypt. Last month, the real estate arm of Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund announced plans to invest $29.7 billion in a luxury real estate and tourism development on Egypt’s Mediterranean coast, the largest Qatari investment in the country since diplomatic relations were restored after the 2017–2021 regional rift.

The deal also comes amid growing regional momentum in sustainable aviation fuel, with MENA Biofuels beginning implementation of the UAE’s first SAF production facility in Fujairah, targeting up to 250 million litres per year as part of the country’s SAF Roadmap 2030.

title: New York Releases Regulation Requiring Mandatory GHG Reporting for Large Emitters from 2027
description:
New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) Commissioner Amanda Lefton announced the finalization of new regulations to implement mandatory greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions disclosure from carbon-intensive sectors, with reporting slated to begin in 2027.
Several states, including New York and California have moved to implement climate disclosure requirements over the past several months.
DEC issued draft regulations in March 2025, and received more than 3,000 public comments on the draft in its consultation.
The finalized regulation included a few changes, including extending the verification reporting deadline for the first two years, and reducing reporting requirements from facilities that closed or ceased operations.
Lefton said: “DEC’s greenhouse gas emissions reporting program and subsequent data collection is critical to the State’s ongoing efforts to protect our environment and improve the health and quality of life of all New Yorkers.”
text:
New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) Commissioner Amanda Lefton announced the finalization of new regulations to implement mandatory greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions disclosure from carbon-intensive sectors, with reporting slated to begin in 2027.

The new reporting requirements come as the federal government under the Trump administration has pulled back on initiatives to provide transparency into corporate and industrial emissions, including plans to by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) end the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program (GHGRP), and moves by the SEC to stop the implementation of its own new climate reporting rules. Several states, including New York and California have moved to implement climate disclosure requirements over the past several months.

Commissioner Lefton said:

“The Reporting Rule will enable DEC to collect the information necessary, despite proposed rollbacks on the federal level, and develop effective strategies that reduce harmful air pollution and direct investments where they are most needed.”

The finalization of DEC’s regulations follows a directive issued by New York Governor Kathy Hochul earlier this year to advance a Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program, aimed at providing information on major polluters in the state, informing policies to reduce GHG emissions and to assess compliance with emissions reduction programs, and to help the state meet its emissions reduction goals.

Under the new regulation, facilities included in the new rules will be required to annually provide certain GHG emission data to DEC starting in June 2027, reflecting the previous year’s emissions. In addition, some large emission sources will also be required to verify their emissions data report annually using DEC-accredited third-party verification services.

Entities required to report under the new regulations include owners and operators of facilities in New York that emit 10,000 metric tons of CO2e annually, including electricity generation, stationary combustion, landfills, waste-to-energy, natural gas compressor stations, and other infrastructure; fuel suppliers including natural gas, liquid fuels, and petroleum products, liquefied natural gas and compressed natural gas, and coal; waste haulers and transporters with estimated emissions from solid wastes transported to landfills or combustion facilities outside of New York exceeding 10,000 MT CO2e in any year; electric power entities; agricultural lime and fertilizer suppliers, and anaerobic digestion and liquid storage of waste at facilities with waste imported to or generated at the facility generating 10,000 MT CO2 per year.

DEC issued draft regulations in March 2025, and received more than 3,000 public comments on the draft in its consultation. The finalized regulation included a few changes, including extending the verification reporting deadline for the first two years, and reducing reporting requirements from facilities that closed or ceased operations.

Lefton said:

“DEC’s greenhouse gas emissions reporting program and subsequent data collection is critical to the State’s ongoing efforts to protect our environment and improve the health and quality of life of all New Yorkers.”

title: IATA: Growth in SAF Production Set to Slow in 2026 - FLYING Magazine
description:
Growth in the production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) will fall short of projections this year and slow down in 2026, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) reported this week.
The trade group estimates that SAF production will reach 1.9 million metric tons in 2025, almost double the amount made in 2024.
“Europe’s fragmented policies distort markets, slow investment, and undermine efforts to scale SAF production,” Willie Walsh, IATA’s director general, said in a statement.
SAF is a renewable alternative to conventional jet fuel made from nonpetroleum feedstocks.
Many airlines and private aviation companies now use SAF, and some have set targets for a gradual transition away from conventional jet fuel.
text:
Growth in the production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) will fall short of projections this year and slow down in 2026, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) reported this week.

The trade group estimates that SAF production will reach 1.9 million metric tons in 2025, almost double the amount made in 2024. But that figure will fall short of IATA’s initial estimates for the year, and in 2026, growth in production is expected to slow to 2.4 million metric tons.

IATA officials placed the blame on “poorly designed” SAF-related mandates and policy frameworks enacted in the U.K. and Europe.

Europe’s ReFuelEU Aviation, for instance, has sharply increased costs, and airlines are now paying up to five times more for SAF than conventional jet fuel, the group said.

“Europe’s fragmented policies distort markets, slow investment, and undermine efforts to scale SAF production,” Willie Walsh, IATA’s director general, said in a statement. “Europe’s regulators must recognize that its approach is not working and urgently correct course.”

The trade association said governments should focus their efforts on production incentives, rather than mandates, to increase the global supply of SAF and drive down prices.

SAF is a renewable alternative to conventional jet fuel made from nonpetroleum feedstocks. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, it can be developed from food and yard waste, woody biomass, agricultural waste, cooking oils, animal fats, and algae.

SAF is a “drop in” fuel, meaning it can be blended with traditional jet fuel and used in existing aircraft engines without requiring modification. Its use can reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 80 percent.

Many airlines and private aviation companies now use SAF, and some have set targets for a gradual transition away from conventional jet fuel. IATA said that, as a result of increasing costs, airlines that have pledged to use 10 percent SAF by 2030 will be “forced to reevaluate these commitments.”

“SAF is not being produced in sufficient amounts to enable these airlines to achieve their ambition,” Walsh said. “These commitments were made in good faith but simply cannot be delivered.”

title: 2026 Outlooks | S&P Global
description:
As we step into 2026, the chorus of voices warning of an impending credit downturn is getting louder.
And yet, we see a number of factors that point to a more balanced--dare we say, resilient--picture ahead.
Against this backdrop, broader policy uncertainty represents a key risk to the outlook and a potential trigger for market volatility.
Trade tensions may have peaked and markets have absorbed them, at least for now.
But they are symptomatic of a long-term shift toward a more transactional and multipolar world order which will have longer term credit implications.
text:
As we step into 2026, the chorus of voices warning of an impending credit downturn is getting louder. And yet, we see a number of factors that point to a more balanced--dare we say, resilient--picture ahead. This includes resilient economies, extended maturities for issuers, and improved interest rates.

At the same time, the rapid scale of AI fundraising, and valuations attained by players, have sparked concerns of possible hubris or the emergence of new risks, with the ultimate transformational nature of AI’s outcomes still anyone’s guess.

Against this backdrop, broader policy uncertainty represents a key risk to the outlook and a potential trigger for market volatility. Trade tensions may have peaked and markets have absorbed them, at least for now. But they are symptomatic of a long-term shift toward a more transactional and multipolar world order which will have longer term credit implications.

title: Demand for Liquid Biofuels in USA | Global Market Analysis Report - 2035
description:
Demand for Liquid Biofuels in USA 2025 to 2035 Demand for liquid biofuels in the USA is projected to grow from USD 36.20 billion in 2025 to approximately USD 55.14 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 18.94 billion over the forecast period.

Analysis of USA Liquid Biofuels Demand by Key Regions Region CAGR (2025-2035) West 4.80% Northeast 4.60% South 4.40% Midwest 4.20% The USA liquid biofuels demand is witnessing steady growth, supported by rising transportation requirements, expanding renewable fuel facility initiatives, and the deployment of advanced biofuel technologies across regions.
Competitive Landscape of USA Liquid Biofuels Industry Liquid biofuels demand in USA is defined by competition among established energy corporations, specialized renewable companies, and integrated transportation producers, with major producer operators maintaining significant influence through production resources and processing capabilities.
text:
Demand for Liquid Biofuels in USA 2025 to 2035

Demand for liquid biofuels in the USA is projected to grow from USD 36.20 billion in 2025 to approximately USD 55.14 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 18.94 billion over the forecast period. This translates into a total growth of 52.3%, with demand forecast to expand at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 4.3% between 2025 and 2035.

The overall demand size is expected to grow by 1.5 times during the same period, supported by increasing renewable fuel standard compliance requirements, rising transportation sector decarbonization initiatives, advancing bioethanol production capabilities, and expanding biodiesel manufacturing infrastructure throughout the USA.

The bioethanol segment is projected to account for 58.70% of liquid biofuels demand in 2025. Bioethanol applications are widely used in the USA for gasoline blending operations, fuel distribution systems, and automotive applications where octane enhancement, proven compatibility, and established infrastructure capabilities remain essential for transportation fuel requirements and renewable energy compliance optimization.

The transportation fuel segment is expected to represent 79.20% of liquid biofuels demand in 2025. Transportation fuel applications are fundamental to the industry because they provide the essential renewable fuel capabilities, emission reduction properties, and regulatory compliance required for automotive gasoline, diesel substitution, and fleet operations.

Between 2020 and 2025, liquid biofuels demand in the USA experienced steady expansion, driven by increasing renewable fuel standard enforcement and growing recognition of energy security requirements for domestic fuel production and carbon emission reduction optimization. The sector developed as fuel suppliers and transportation companies, especially in major metropolitan areas, recognized the need for renewable fuel alternatives and effective blending solutions to achieve regulatory objectives while meeting federal compliance standards and performance requirements. Energy companies and fuel distributors began emphasizing domestic production and renewable alternatives to maintain competitive advantages and regulatory compliance.

Between 2025 and 2030, demand for liquid biofuels in the USA is projected to expand from USD 36.20 billion to USD 44.81 billion, resulting in a value increase of USD 8.61 billion, which represents 45.5% of the total forecast growth for the decade. This phase of growth will be shaped by accelerating transportation decarbonization requirements, rising renewable fuel production capabilities, and growing federal policy support for advanced biofuel systems across USA regions, particularly in areas where agricultural processing infrastructure and renewable energy development initiatives are accelerating biofuel adoption. Increasing integration of advanced ethanol systems and growing adoption of biodiesel compatibility platforms continue to drive demand.

Energy companies and biofuel producers are expanding their production capabilities to address the growing complexity of modern transportation requirements and renewable fuel standards, with USA operations leading investments in conventional processing enhancement methods and efficient feedstock optimization systems.

From 2030 to 2035, demand is forecast to grow from USD 44.81 billion to USD 55.14 billion, adding another USD 10.33 billion, which constitutes 54.5% of the overall ten-year expansion. This period is expected to be characterized by expansion of advanced biofuel applications, development of enhanced sustainable fuel capabilities, and implementation of comprehensive liquid biofuel technology programs across different transportation and energy sectors. The growing adoption of next-generation renewable fuel systems and enhanced carbon reduction platforms, particularly in major agricultural regions and processing operations, will drive demand for more sophisticated biofuel solutions and validated renewable fuel systems.

USA Liquid Biofuels Industry Key Takeaways

Metric Value USA Liquid Biofuels Sales Value (2025) USD 36.20 billion USA Liquid Biofuels Forecast Value (2035) USD 55.14 billion USA Liquid Biofuels Forecast CAGR (2025-2035) 4.3%

Why is the USA Liquid Biofuels Industry Growing?

The USA liquid biofuels industry is experiencing robust growth, primarily fueled by a parallel expansion in the broader renewable fuel standard compliance sector. A significant surge in demand for both transportation fuel decarbonization and advanced renewable fuel alternatives has created a larger base of energy companies, fuel distributors, and transportation operators requiring reliable biofuel products.

Changing federal regulations and EPA renewable fuel standards mandate the use of efficient renewable fuel systems for optimal emission reduction and energy security optimization. This policy-driven demand establishes a consistent, regulation-based foundation. As new operators enter the renewable fuel production segment and existing transportation practices are modernized, the need for standard-issue and specialized biofuel products forms a stable foundation for the industry's growth, ensuring a continuous stream of customers driven by regulatory necessity and compliance requirements.

Technological innovation serves as a powerful secondary engine for this growth. Modern liquid biofuel systems are no longer just basic ethanol alternatives; they are advanced renewable fuel products. The rapid adoption of specialized bioethanol technologies has become a major selling point, significantly reducing blending complexity and enhancing fuel performance. Beyond traditional options, producers are integrating advanced formulations for seamless incorporation with digitally conscious fuel approaches, and compatibility with various distribution requirements. These features, coupled with improvements in carbon intensity, system convenience, and product quality, are compelling both energy and transportation operators to upgrade from conventional fuel systems, driving a cycle of replacement and premiumization within the industry.

The industry is benefiting from evolving energy dynamics and a heightened focus on renewable fuel experience. An increasing emphasis on emission reduction, particularly exploration of advanced renewable fuel technologies, is pushing demand for higher-quality, more diverse biofuel varieties. The segment has also expanded beyond traditional transportation channels, with growing interest from the power generation sector, industrial applications, and even thermal heating units. This diversification, combined with the rise of specialized platforms that improve accessibility for all producers, ensures that suppliers can reach a wider audience than ever before. This confluence of efficiency, innovation, and accessibility creates a fertile ground for continued industry expansion.

Opportunity Pathways - Demand for Liquid Biofuels in the USA

The liquid biofuels industry in the USA is positioned for strong and steady expansion, growing from USD 36.20 billion in 2025 to USD 55.14 billion by 2035, reflecting a 4.5% CAGR. This growth is driven by the rising adoption of advanced, renewable fuel systems in transportation applications, power generation facilities, and thermal heating operations. Operators are seeking specialized biofuel solutions that maximize emission reduction, regulatory compliance, and production efficiency amidst stringent EPA standards.

Demand from sustainable aviation fuel trends, renewable diesel innovations, and distributed energy implementations strengthens opportunities for both high-performance ethanol formulations and integrated renewable fuel solutions. Suppliers focusing on corn-based bioethanol, soybean biodiesel, and advanced feedstock processing stand to gain from evolving regulatory landscapes and producer expectations for fuel traceability, carbon reduction assurance, and technical documentation completeness.

Pathway A - Advanced Bioethanol Production and Blending. Producers face escalating demand for reliable, cost-effective ethanol for the high-volume blending of gasoline fuels. Solutions targeting flex-fuel vehicles, conventional blending, and distribution systems can achieve strong adoption through optimized processing, purity, and storage compatibility. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 6.8-9.2 billion.

Pathway B - Biodiesel Manufacturing and Distribution. The transportation industry requires increasingly sophisticated renewable diesel alternatives and biodiesel blending solutions. Collaborations with fleet operators for integrated fuel supply systems (e.g., trucking fleets, marine applications, heating oil) can unlock long-term supply contracts and partnerships. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 5.1-7.3 billion.

Pathway C - Sustainable Aviation Fuel Development. Growth in aviation decarbonization and renewable jet fuel applications creates robust demand for ASTM-compliant and carbon-neutral biofuel alternatives. Suppliers offering proven aviation-grade fuels with exceptional performance characteristics and regulatory approval can build strategic relationships with major airline operators. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 3.8-5.4 billion.

Pathway D - Industrial and Power Generation Applications. Manufacturing requirements for renewable energy, carbon reduction, and emission compliance are driving preference for specialized biofuels in industrial heating, power generation, and thermal applications. Suppliers offering fuels with exceptional energy content and emission profiles can differentiate offerings and attract efficiency-focused organizations. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 2.9-4.1 billion.

Pathway E - Advanced Feedstock Processing. Critical applications in cellulosic ethanol, waste-to-fuel processing, and alternative feedstock utilization require specialized production configurations with advanced conversion efficiency, feedstock flexibility, and environmental benefits. Suppliers investing in technology development for next-generation fuels can secure advantages in this demanding segment. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 2.2-3.6 billion.

Pathway F - Technical Service, Certification & Regulatory Support. Comprehensive support networks offering fuel specification guidance, full regulatory documentation (RFS compliance), and production process validation create recurring partnership opportunities. Companies building strong technical service capabilities can capture ongoing relationships and enhance customer speed-to-production. Estimated revenue opportunity: USD 1.4-2.0 billion.

Segmental Analysis

The industry is segmented by product, application, and region. By product, the industry is divided into bioethanol, biodiesel, and others. In terms of application, the industry is segmented into transportation fuel, power generation, thermal heating, with transportation fuel representing a key growth and innovation hub for renewable energy technologies. Regionally, the industry is divided into West, Northeast, South, and Midwest.

Which Category Dominates in USA’s Liquid Biofuels Industry by Product?

The bioethanol segment is projected to account for 58.70% of liquid biofuels demand in 2025, making it the leading product type across the sector. This dominance reflects the infrastructure compatibility requirements and cost acceptance needs of renewable fuel systems for existing transportation facilities and fuel distribution applications where octane enhancement is optimized through established performance characteristics and integrated blending architecture.

In the USA, where substantial transportation infrastructure requires fuel integration without complete system redesign, bioethanol solutions provide practical pathways for emission reduction while maintaining cost preferences. Continuous innovations are improving octane performance, blending compatibility, and renewable parameters, enabling transportation operators to achieve high emission reduction standards while maximizing cost effectiveness.

Cost compatibility and existing system integration make bioethanol the preferred product type for enhancing transportation facilities and fuel operations.

Blending reliability and performance demonstration track records are enhancing producer confidence and distribution viability across large-scale adoption initiatives.

Which Application Category Generates Maximum Demand for Liquid Biofuels in USA?

Transportation fuel applications are expected to represent 79.20% of liquid biofuels demand in 2025, reflecting the critical role of renewable fuel alternatives requiring comprehensive emission reduction solutions. Transportation fuel operations including automotive projects, fleet facilities, and distribution systems generate consistent demand for biofuels that support efficient transportation utilization and performance optimization.

Biofuel systems are widely adopted for transportation fuel facilities due to significant emission benefits and enhanced renewable energy capabilities. Their reliable, high-performance operation provides effective, cost-efficient emission reduction solutions, enhancing energy independence for transportation fuel users.

Renewable fuel requirements and emission reduction operations drive substantial demand for specialized biofuels designed for transportation applications.

Carbon optimization and performance efficiency demands create consistent emission reduction requirements across major transportation regions and distribution facilities.

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends in the USA Liquid Biofuels Industry?

The demand for liquid biofuels in the USA is advancing steadily due to increasing transportation requirements and growing recognition of renewable fuel necessity for regulatory compliance, with the West region serving as a key driver of innovation and renewable energy advancement.

The sector faces challenges including feedstock cost volatility optimization, production enhancement complexity, and ongoing concerns regarding regulatory cost considerations and approval variations.

Growth in Renewable Fuel Standard Implementation and Transportation Decarbonization Programs

The enhancement of production standards, gaining particular significance through transportation decarbonization trends and emission education campaigns, is enabling biofuel providers to achieve differentiation without prohibitive development costs, providing predictable demand patterns through regulatory requirements and producer preferences.

Enhanced production standards offering substantial opportunities for biofuel systems and integrated applications provide foundational dynamics while allowing providers to secure transportation facility agreements and distribution partnerships.

Deployment of Advanced Ethanol Capabilities and High-Performance Renewable Systems

Modern biofuel providers and energy operators are establishing advanced production networks and centralized processing facilities that improve manufacturing efficiency through process standardization and renewable analytics.

Integration of renewable enhancement systems, high-performance fuel technology, and coordinated quality management enables more efficient production operations across multiple processing regions.

Development of Next-Generation Fuel Systems and Enhanced Carbon Reduction Methods

The expansion of next-generation fuel systems and emission targeting is driving development of specialized biofuel systems with enhanced renewable profiles, improved performance characteristics, and optimized carbon attributes that address current limitations and expand transportation applications beyond traditional fuels.

These specialized systems require sophisticated renewable capabilities and performance expertise that exceed traditional production requirements, creating specialized demand segments with differentiated emission propositions. Producers are investing in carbon targeting and renewable optimization to serve emerging transportation applications while supporting innovation in performance development and emission engagement.

Analysis of USA Liquid Biofuels Demand by Key Regions

Region CAGR (2025-2035) West 4.80% Northeast 4.60% South 4.40% Midwest 4.20%

The USA liquid biofuels demand is witnessing steady growth, supported by rising transportation requirements, expanding renewable fuel facility initiatives, and the deployment of advanced biofuel technologies across regions. West leads the nation with a 4.80% CAGR, reflecting a strong innovation-conscious base, substantial renewable energy development, and established transportation advancement facilities.

Why Does the West Region Lead Liquid Biofuels Demand?

Demand for liquid biofuels in West is projected to exhibit strong growth with a CAGR of 4.80% through 2035, driven by a strong innovation-conscious energy base, substantial renewable fuel development creating premium biofuel opportunities, and a concentration of production advancement across California, Oregon, Washington, Nevada, and surrounding states.

Advanced renewable energy programs and carbon control initiatives are expanding biofuel adoption among producers, energy facilities, and transportation suppliers pursuing performance optimization, emission development, and specialized renewable projects throughout major urban hubs and production corridors.

Innovation consciousness base and energy infrastructure capabilities are requiring comprehensive renewable strategies and emission solutions, driving demand for biofuel systems with demonstrated performance enhancement capabilities and permanent carbon assurance throughout diverse energy operations.

Renewable fuel development and energy concentration are generating substantial biofuel demand across energy companies, producers, and emission suppliers serving transportation applications and renewable requirements.

Why Does the Northeast Region Demonstrate Strong Growth?

Demand for liquid biofuels in Northeast is projected to grow with a CAGR of 4.60% through 2035, supported by established energy presence, comprehensive renewable fuel development, and strong production facilities across New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, New Jersey, and surrounding states.

Established energy presence and production leadership are supporting biofuel adoption throughout producer facilities, renewable fuel operations, and emission distribution centers serving performance enhancement and renewable applications.

Strong energy ecosystem and production networks are enabling biofuel integration across emission producers, manufacturers, and renewable suppliers pursuing advanced performance development and energy programs.

Premium renewable fuel capabilities and emission excellence are driving biofuel demand among leading producer corporations, energy centers, and specialized emission firms focused on performance enhancement, renewable optimization, and production development targeting transportation applications and advanced energy operations.

What Factors Underpin Liquid Biofuels Demand in South Region?

Demand for liquid biofuels in South is forecast to advance with a CAGR of 4.40% through 2035, driven by expanding energy capabilities, growing renewable investment, and increasing emission consciousness across Texas, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, and surrounding states.

Rising renewable fuel sector development and production partnerships are supporting biofuel integration across renewable producers, producer facilities, and emission distributors pursuing performance enhancement, energy expansion, and renewable initiatives throughout expanding energy regions and urban centers.

Growing energy infrastructure and renewable fuel investment are creating opportunities for biofuel adoption across emerging renewable hubs, producer facilities, and emission distribution centers in major metropolitan areas and energy corridors.

Performance expansion and emission growth are driving biofuel demand among energy operators seeking enhanced performance capabilities and participation in advanced renewable programs.

What Boosts Consistent Demand in the Midwest Region?

Demand for liquid biofuels in Midwest is expected to expand with a CAGR of 4.20% through 2035, supported by renewable production capabilities, energy infrastructure development, and growing producer efficiency presence across Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan, and surrounding states.

Emission expertise and production capabilities are driving biofuel demand among renewable producers, energy suppliers, and transportation manufacturers serving biofuel production and performance applications.

Growing renewable development and production investment are supporting biofuel adoption across emerging production hubs, energy facilities, and producer centers pursuing performance enhancement and renewable programs.

Expanding energy infrastructure and renewable integration are creating opportunities for biofuel utilization across emission suppliers, energy production facilities, and producer operations seeking performance biofuel production, emission support, and production capabilities throughout major energy regions and emerging producer emission centers.

Competitive Landscape of USA Liquid Biofuels Industry

Liquid biofuels demand in USA is defined by competition among established energy corporations, specialized renewable companies, and integrated transportation producers, with major producer operators maintaining significant influence through production resources and processing capabilities. Companies are investing in biofuel advancement, renewable optimization, emission acceptance technologies, and comprehensive performance services to deliver effective, reliable, and efficient renewable solutions across USA transportation and producer applications.

Archer Daniels Midland Company dominates with a 14.20% share, offering comprehensive renewable solutions including advanced equipment, performance enhancement technologies, and distribution services with a focus on transportation applications, emission consistency, and renewable optimization across USA operations. The company continues investing in renewable programs, distribution strategies, and biofuel innovation while expanding operational presence and advanced producer applications.

Green Plains Incorporated provides specialized renewable solutions with emphasis on performance development and production excellence. Gevo Incorporated focuses on premium biofuel development and transportation applications. Valero Energy Corporation emphasizes performance development and specialized producer equipment production. Pacific Ethanol Incorporated offers renewable technology solutions and professional performance support. Renewable Energy Group Incorporated specializes in transportation biofuel development and distribution programs.

title: Sinopec - Facebook
description:
Sinopec Ningbo Zhenhai Refining & Chemical Co., Ltd. has achieved a major milestone in sustainable aviation fuel development, as its sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) recently received International Sustainability and Carbon Certification under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (ISCC CORSIA).
This is the second international sustainable green certification that the company has gained for its SAF following the certification from the Roundtable on Sustainable Biomaterials (RSB).
SAF is produced from renewable feedstocks such as animal and vegetable oils and used cooking oil.
The company operates China's first large-scale SAF production facility, with an annual capacity of 100,000 tonnes.
This capacity enables the recycling of used cooking oil equivalent to the amount generated by a city of 10 million people.

title: Egypt, Qatar's Al Mana Holding sign $200mln sustainable aviation fuel deal - ZAWYA
description:
CAIRO: Egypt signed a contract with Qatar's Al Mana Holding ‍for a first-phase ‍investment of $200 million to produce sustainable aviation fuel from ​used cooking oil in the Suez Canal Economic Zone at Ain ⁠Sokhna, Egypt's cabinet said on Sunday.
The project will be developed in ⁠three phases ‌and will span 100,000 square metres in the Integrated Sokhna Zone on Egypt's Red Sea coast.
The first ⁠phase will have an estimated annual production capacity of 200,000 tonnes, the cabinet said in a statement.
The deal marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, ⁠Egypt said.
Last month, the real estate arm of Qatar's sovereign wealth fund said it would invest $29.7 billion to develop a luxury real estate and tourism project on Egypt's Mediterranean coast.
text:
CAIRO: Egypt signed a contract with Qatar's Al Mana Holding ‍for a first-phase ‍investment of $200 million to produce sustainable aviation fuel from ​used cooking oil in the Suez Canal Economic Zone at Ain ⁠Sokhna, Egypt's cabinet said on Sunday.

The project will be developed in ⁠three phases ‌and will span 100,000 square metres in the Integrated Sokhna Zone on Egypt's Red Sea coast. The first ⁠phase will have an estimated annual production capacity of 200,000 tonnes, the cabinet said in a statement.

The deal marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal Economic Zone, ⁠Egypt said.

Egypt has for ​years been pushing to secure foreign investments, especially from wealthy Gulf states, as it ‍seeks to tackle heavy foreign debts and a gaping budget deficit.

Prime Minister ​Mostafa Madbouly said the project "reflects the positive momentum in relations between Cairo and Doha, driven by the shared political will to advance bilateral cooperation through joint investments and increased trade."

Last month, the real estate arm of Qatar's sovereign wealth fund said it would invest $29.7 billion to develop a luxury real estate and tourism project on Egypt's Mediterranean coast.

That deal marked the largest Qatari investment in ⁠the country since diplomatic relations were restored ‌following a 2017–2021 economic rift when Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Bahrain cut ties with Qatar, accusing it of ‌supporting terrorism and ⁠aligning too closely with Iran, charges Doha denied. (Reporting by Momen Saeed ⁠Atallah Writing by Hatem Maher Editing by Peter Graff)

title: IATA Warns Poor Policy is Slowing Production Growth, Increasing Price of Sustainable Aviation Fuel
description:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) announced the release of new estimates for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production, predicting that output of SAF will reach 1.9 million tonnes (Mt) (2.4 billion liters), nearly doubling the 1 Mt produced in 2024.
Moreover, the slowdown in SAF production growth follows the implementation by the EU and UK this year of new SAF-focused mandates, requiring minimum, and increasing, amounts of SAF usage, causing prices for sustainable aviation fuel to increase sharply.
IATA General Director Willie Walsh said: “If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park.
Walsh also warned that the failure to accelerate SAF production will lead airlines with SAF targets to review their goals, noting that “many airlines that have committed to use 10% SAF by 2030 will be forced to reevaluate these commitments.
SAF is not being produced in sufficient amounts to enable these airlines to achieve their ambition.” Walsh added:
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) announced the release of new estimates for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production, predicting that output of SAF will reach 1.9 million tonnes (Mt) (2.4 billion liters), nearly doubling the 1 Mt produced in 2024.

While substantially outpacing the prior year’s production, however, the new forecast marks a reduction in the IATA’s estimate for 2025 SAF output from its prior 2 Mt prediction, with the IATA noting that 2025 production will only account for 0.6% of total jet fuel consumption this year, and blaming the downward revision on a “lack of policy support to take full advantage of the installed SAF capacities.”

Additionally, the IATA warned that it anticipates that production growth will slow significantly next year, reaching 2.4 Mt in 2026, or 0.8% of jet fuel consumption.

Moreover, the slowdown in SAF production growth follows the implementation by the EU and UK this year of new SAF-focused mandates, requiring minimum, and increasing, amounts of SAF usage, causing prices for sustainable aviation fuel to increase sharply. According to the IATA, SAF prices exceed fossil-based jet fuel by a factor of two, and by up to a factor of five in mandated markets, with the IATA estimating that poorly designed mandates have led to airlines paying a $2.9 billion premium in 2025 for SAF.

IATA General Director Willie Walsh said:

“If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park. But if the objective is to increase SAF production to further the decarbonization of aviation, then they need to learn from failure and work with the airline industry to design incentives that will work.”

Fuel accounts for the vast majority of the aviation sector’s emissions. Generally produced from sustainable resources, like waste oils and agricultural residues, SAF is seen as one of the key tools to help decarbonize the aviation industry in the near- to medium-term. SAF producers estimate the fuels can result in lifecycle GHG emissions reductions of as much as 85% relative to conventional fuels. Efforts to meaningfully increase the use of SAF by airlines face significant challenges, including the low supply currently available on the market, and prices currently well above those of conventional fossil-based fuels.

Walsh also warned that the failure to accelerate SAF production will lead airlines with SAF targets to review their goals, noting that “many airlines that have committed to use 10% SAF by 2030 will be forced to reevaluate these commitments. SAF is not being produced in sufficient amounts to enable these airlines to achieve their ambition.”

Walsh added:

title: Egypt And Qatar's Al Mana Holding Sign $200 Million Sustainable Aviation Fuel Deal
description:
Egypt has signed a $200 million agreement with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding to develop sustainable aviation fuel production, marking a significant step in the country’s push to green its aviation sector.
The deal was signed through Egypt’s Ministry of Civil Aviation and targets the local production of SAF to reduce carbon emissions and support global climate commitments, as disclosed by the ministry.
Authorities said the investment aligns with Egypt’s long-term strategy to position itself as a regional hub for sustainable aviation fuels.
Al Mana Holding said the agreement reflects growing Gulf interest in Egypt’s energy transition and aviation infrastructure.
The Qatari conglomerate noted that Egypt’s strategic location and expanding air traffic make it an attractive base for SAF production, as outlined in comments released by the company.
text:
Egypt has signed a $200 million agreement with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding to develop sustainable aviation fuel production, marking a significant step in the country’s push to green its aviation sector. The deal was signed through Egypt’s Ministry of Civil Aviation and targets the local production of SAF to reduce carbon emissions and support global climate commitments, as disclosed by the ministry.

According to statements from Egyptian aviation officials, the project will focus on building production capacity using environmentally friendly feedstocks, with output aimed at serving both domestic airlines and international carriers operating through Egypt’s major airports. Authorities said the investment aligns with Egypt’s long-term strategy to position itself as a regional hub for sustainable aviation fuels.

Al Mana Holding said the agreement reflects growing Gulf interest in Egypt’s energy transition and aviation infrastructure. The Qatari conglomerate noted that Egypt’s strategic location and expanding air traffic make it an attractive base for SAF production, as outlined in comments released by the company.

title: SBTi Pilots New Draft Power Sector Net Zero Standard - ESG Today
description:
The Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) announced the launch of the pilot phase for its new draft Power Sector Net-Zero Standard, inviting companies to test the proposed standard aimed at enabling companies across the power sector to set near- and long-term goals aligned with achieving net zero by 2050.
The organization published its flagship cross-sector Corporate Net-Zero Standard in 2021, and is currently in the process of developing an update to the standard, Corporate Net-Zero Standard V2.
The new proposed standard was developed in alignment with the SBTi’s draft Net-Zero Standard V2, while also introducing new methodologies and requirements specific to power sector companies.
The new pilot follows the conclusion of an initial consultation on the draft power sector standard.
As renewable energy deployment accelerates and decarbonization becomes increasingly urgent, the power sector is central to the global transition to net-zero.
text:
The Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) announced the launch of the pilot phase for its new draft Power Sector Net-Zero Standard, inviting companies to test the proposed standard aimed at enabling companies across the power sector to set near- and long-term goals aligned with achieving net zero by 2050.

The SBTi released the draft standard in September 2025, set to replace its current “Quick Start Guide for Electric Utilities” with a new standard covering an expanded scope and a broader set of activities and emission sources across the sector’s value chain, for companies involved in power generation, transmission and distribution, and electricity storage, trade and retail.

The SBTi was founded in 2015 with the goal to establish science-based environmental target setting as a standard corporate practice. The organizations’ key functions include defining and promoting best practice in emissions reductions and net-zero targets in line with climate science, providing technical assistance to companies who set science-based targets, and providing companies with independent assessment and validation of their emissions reduction targets. To date, nearly 12,000 companies have set science-based emissions reduction targets with the SBTi, or made commitments to do so.

The organization published its flagship cross-sector Corporate Net-Zero Standard in 2021, and is currently in the process of developing an update to the standard, Corporate Net-Zero Standard V2. The new proposed standard was developed in alignment with the SBTi’s draft Net-Zero Standard V2, while also introducing new methodologies and requirements specific to power sector companies.

One of the key new criteria in the draft standard is a requirement for power sector companies to “publicly disclose a plan to transition away from unabated fossil fuel power generation,” which includes “interim actions to decarbonise, phase-out or retrofit unabated fossil fuel assets, with maximum 5-years milestones up to the net-zero year.” The proposed standard also requires companies to cease investing in new unabated fossil fuel capacity.

The new pilot follows the conclusion of an initial consultation on the draft power sector standard. According to the SBTi, key objectives of the pilot test include ensuring that the new standard and target setting tool are robust, clear and practical, identifying challenges for implementing the standard, informing the development of the final draft of the standard, and testing the feasibility of validating companies against the standard and the clarity of the requirements.

The SBTi said that it is inviting companies across power generation, transmission and distribution, storage, trading, and retail to take part in the new pilot, with applications to participate open until January 16, 2026. Feedback from the consultation and pilot will be used to develop the next draft of the standard

The SBTi said:

“Electricity underpins day to day life and the global economy—from powering homes and industry to enabling digital technologies and innovation. Yet, energy is currently responsible for more than 75% of total global greenhouse gas emissions. As renewable energy deployment accelerates and decarbonization becomes increasingly urgent, the power sector is central to the global transition to net-zero. Establishing a robust, science-based standard is essential for ensuring this transition is both credible and effective.”

title: Spain's biogas and biomethane sector: opportunities, challenges and outlook
description:
Our Energy team examines the evolution of Spain’s biogas and biomethane market, highlighting opportunities and regulatory challenges.
How do you see Spain’s biogas and biomethane market evolving in the coming years?
The updated Integrated National Energy and Climate Plan (Plan Nacional Integrado de Energía y Clima – PNIEC) targets 20 TWh of biogas and biomethane by 2030.
What measures could make Spain’s biogas and biomethane market more competitive?
Spain is the third country with the highest biogas production potential in the European Union (163 TWh annually), behind Germany and France.
text:
Our Energy team examines the evolution of Spain’s biogas and biomethane market, highlighting opportunities and regulatory challenges. With production potential placing Spain among Europe’s leaders, we outline key measures to create a competitive regulatory framework and foster sustainable investment and project development.

How do you see Spain’s biogas and biomethane market evolving in the coming years?

The updated Integrated National Energy and Climate Plan (Plan Nacional Integrado de Energía y Clima – PNIEC) targets 20 TWh of biogas and biomethane by 2030. Yet, in 2024, production was only 319 GWh (according to the CNMC), underscoring the need for optimal conditions to attract investment. Although a growth trend is evident, the sector currently meets just 0.163% of Spain’s gas demand. In short, significant expansion is expected, given its early stage and numerous projects under development.

What are the main regulatory or permitting challenges for developers in Spain?

The absence of a dedicated biomethane framework is one of the main current challenges. Regulation remains fragmented and subject to inconsistent regional interpretations, complicating efficient project delivery. Developers must consider raw material proximity, network access, and social opposition, while navigating frequent rule changes on grid capacity and opaque processes for gas network connections. This situation, combined with the conditional injection capacity currently granted to such projects, further limits project appeal.

What measures could make Spain’s biogas and biomethane market more competitive?

Spain is the third country with the highest biogas production potential in the European Union (163 TWh annually), behind Germany and France.

To unlock this potential, Spanish lawmakers could:

(i) grant biomethane projects public utility status;

(ii) grant them preferential demand access capacity to the electricity grid without subjecting them to capacity tenders;

(iii) guarantee injection capacity into natural gas networks by amending current regulations that only allow conditional capacity; and

(iv) create a basic, specific, state-level regulatory framework.

Public authorities should also promote awareness campaigns to increase social acceptance of these projects, while developers should prioritise responsible, safe, sustainable and transparent development.

title: Qatar enters Egypt's Suez Canal zone with $200mln SAF investment - Ecofin Agency
description:
Egypt signed a $200 million SAF investment deal with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding.
The project marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal zone.
Al Mana Holding has secured a long-term supply agreement with Shell, which has committed to purchasing the entire output of the facility.
Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly, who attended the signing ceremony, said the initiative with Al Mana Holding reflects the positive momentum in relations between Cairo and Doha.
Its chairman, Walid Gamal El-Din, said the use of sustainable aviation fuel could reduce harmful emissions by between 50% and 80% compared with conventional fuels.
text:
Egypt signed a $200 million SAF investment deal with Qatar’s Al Mana Holding.

The project marks the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal zone.

Production is set to start by 2027 under a long-term offtake deal with Shell.

On December 14, on the sidelines of the Egypt–Qatar Business Forum held in Cairo, Egypt signed an agreement with Qatari conglomerate Al Mana Holding for an initial $200 million investment in a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production project. The facility will be located in the integrated Sokhna zone on the Red Sea and represents, according to Egyptian authorities, the first Qatari industrial investment in the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZONE).

The project will be developed by a newly created entity, Saf Fly, and rolled out in three phases. The first phase is expected to deliver annual production capacity of about 200,000 tons, including SAF, biopropane, and bionaphtha, all derived from refined used cooking oil. Al Mana Holding has secured a long-term supply agreement with Shell, which has committed to purchasing the entire output of the facility. Initial deliveries are expected by the end of 2027, providing early visibility on market outlets and reducing commercialization risks.

The agreement forms part of Egypt’s broader strategy to develop low-carbon aviation fuels. On December 4, the country awarded its first SAF production license to the Egyptian Sustainable Aviation Fuel Company (ESAF), a subsidiary of the state-owned petrochemical holding company ECHEM, for a separate project in Alexandria.

Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly, who attended the signing ceremony, said the initiative with Al Mana Holding reflects the positive momentum in relations between Cairo and Doha. He noted that the project aligns with a shared political commitment to strengthen bilateral cooperation through joint investments and increased trade flows.

SCZONE authorities highlighted the project’s alignment with the area’s sustainability strategy. Its chairman, Walid Gamal El-Din, said the use of sustainable aviation fuel could reduce harmful emissions by between 50% and 80% compared with conventional fuels. He also emphasized the zone’s growing appeal for industrial investors, citing its infrastructure, diversified energy sources, and supportive regulatory framework.

Globally, SAF use is expanding, with more than 360,000 commercial flights having already used the fuel, according to the International Civil Aviation Organization. In Africa, airlines such as Ethiopian Airlines and Kenya Airways are planning to adopt SAF in the coming years.

title: Strategic Realignment: Qatar Accelerates Economic Return to Egypt Amidst Regional FDI ...
description:
Bilateral trade surged 80% to hit $143m in 10 months, while Al Mana Holding committed $200m to a sustainable aviation fuel plant in Egypt.
Qatar’s return follows the UAE’s historic $35bn Ras El Hekma deal, marking a competitive shift in Gulf capital flow toward the Nile Valley.
Ranked 9th globally for FDI in 2024, Egypt is negotiating the Alam El-Roum coastal project with Qatari Diar to rival Emirati developments.
Official data released during the Egypt-Qatar Investment Forum reveals that bilateral trade volume increased by 80% during the first ten months of 2025, reaching $143 million.
Qatar’s economic re-entry must be analyzed against the backdrop of massive regional competition, particularly from the United Arab Emirates.
text:
Bilateral trade surged 80% to hit $143m in 10 months, while Al Mana Holding committed $200m to a sustainable aviation fuel plant in Egypt.

Qatar’s return follows the UAE’s historic $35bn Ras El Hekma deal, marking a competitive shift in Gulf capital flow toward the Nile Valley.

Ranked 9th globally for FDI in 2024, Egypt is negotiating the Alam El-Roum coastal project with Qatari Diar to rival Emirati developments.

The rapid thawing of diplomatic relations between Cairo and Doha has crystallized into tangible economic metrics. Official data released during the Egypt-Qatar Investment Forum reveals that bilateral trade volume increased by 80% during the first ten months of 2025, reaching $143 million.

While this volume remains modest in absolute terms relative to Egypt's total trade balance, the trajectory indicates a sharp political pivot. This normalization was cemented by the announcement from Al Mana Holding, a leading Qatari conglomerate, of a $200 million investment to construct a Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) plant. This project targets Egypt’s energy sector, leveraging the country's strategic position to supply green fuels to global logistics networks.

Qatar’s economic re-entry must be analyzed against the backdrop of massive regional competition, particularly from the United Arab Emirates. In early 2024, the UAE signed the Ras El Hekma deal, a historic $35 billion acquisition that stabilized the Egyptian pound and catalyzed a 154% increase in FDI inflows to the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) region which includes Egypt and Ethiopia among 21 other countries.

In response to this Emirati dominance on Egypt's North Coast, negotiations have advanced regarding the Alam El-Roum peninsula. Reports indicate that Qatari Diar is positioning itself to develop this strategic coastal zone, a move that would signal Doha’s transition from smaller industrial investments to large-scale real estate and tourism infrastructure, directly rivaling the Emirati footprint.

The timing of these investments aligns with Egypt’s improved standing in global capital markets following structural reforms supported by the IMF. According to the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and local economic reports, Egypt ranked as the 9th largst recipient of Foreign Direct Investment globally in 2024.

This macroeconomic stabilization has altered the risk profile for Gulf investors. For Qatar, the current strategy is distinct from previous eras of financial aid; it represents a pragmatic pursuit of high-yield assets in a market that has been de-risked by multilateral support and competitor capital. The focus has shifted from liquidity injection to long-term equity in energy, logistics, and prime real estate.
